text: Underwater. Shafts of eroded light slice into the depths of the Hudso River. The ghostly melody of "Lili Marlene," the ache of war-time lover, plays as a strange SHADOW drifts into vie We realize it is a BODY.

Some things, once you've loved them, become yours forever. The body BREAKS the surface and we see the face of its ow ---- DAVID KAMMERER, 33, bearded, handsome. He is clothed white shirt, khakis. Dead.

And if you try to let them go... Suddenly, a breath: he comes back to life. David floats back to LUCIEN CARR, 20, (blonde, beautiful, shirtless and terrified), waist deep in the water. The scene is playing in REVERSE MOTION.
They only circle back and return to you. David's body LIFTS into the young man's arms. We see Davi feet and hands are TIED together with shoelaces. Stones r back into his pockets.
They become part of who you are... A stain of blood on David's chest shrinks, vanishes. David's eyes OPEN.
...or they destroy you. From behind the bars of a jail cell, Lucien Carr (the you man from the opening) finishes reading from a paper MANUSCRIPT in his hand.
Lucien, furious, crumples it up.

You can't show this to anyone. We PULL BACK to reveal the author of the manuscript: a eighteen-year-old ALLEN GINSBERG. Unslept and exhausted. determined. Allen stares defiantly at Lucien from the other side of t bars.
Then tell the truth, Lu.
You weren't even there. It's your truth. It's fiction. Allen grabs for his manuscript back, but Lucien pulls it of reach.

You wanted him gone too. You sent him to me. Allen reaches through the bars and SNATCHES the paper. Lucien won't let go -- it's a tug of war between the two boys, two wills. Allen yanks the paper from Lucien's grip wins. Lucien, panicking.
Please. You'll kill me with that. Allen turns and races towards the exit of the prison. Desperate, Lucien calls out after him.
Allen! No! Allen doesn't turn. An alarm HAMMERS through the prison.
Allen!   No! DON'T...! CUT TO BLACK.
Over a strip of working-class row homes, we hear the soun of a radio announcer giving a dispatch from the war front
American daylight bombers were busy again, as our liberators with fighter escort continue the air offensive with another sock at German coastal installations in France.
The radio continues playing to a modest home. We see a yo man cleaning house, sweeping in the background.

But the Germans report a big new red army push toward Romania. This is World War news. As the war report ends, a stuffy musical piece begins. We hear a groan from the young man. From out of the background emerges Allen Ginsberg (now 17 fresh-faced, horn-rimmed glasses, dutiful son). The kind kid who takes care of everything. He storms up to the radio, switches the station to a fast paced boogie-woogie number. He smiles and dances joyfully the up-beat number with his broom. The door slams. Allen looks up, caught in the act, to see father LOUIS (40's, school teacher, Jewish working-class poet) home from work. Allen accidentally drops the broom.
How was she today? Louis turns off the music. The playful mood dies. Allen s the mail in his father's hand.
Fine. Anything for me?
Why? You expecting something? Allen looks down, a bad liar.
No. Suddenly, from upstairs, the sound of glass shattering. T a woman whimpering in pain. Allen, worried, looks off, dr in his face. His father just sighs.
I told you it wouldn't work. Allen rushes upstairs.
Allen runs into a dark room, flips on the light.
Mom? His mother NAOMI (early 40's, Jewish, deep personality disorder) squats in the corner of the room, in a dirty bathrobe. Her knuckles are bleeding.

You've got to get me out of here. He nailed the windows shut while I was in the bath. She motions to the shattered window pane across the room. Allen sees her blood on the sill, where she tried to esca He moves towards her, to console her. What he's good at.
Dad didn't do that. I nailed the windows. Because you're not right. Naomi, in the midst of a paranoid attack, puts her finger her mouth.
Shhh...Allen. He can hear you! Allen wraps his mother's hand with a dish towel.
You have to rest. Clear your head. Do you want to go back to Greystone?
He wouldn't dare put me back there.
Then listen to me.
SHHHH. He can hear you! She's losing it. Allen quickly thinks, turns to her burea He pulls out a RECORD, starts the phonograph and turns up volume.
Can he still hear me? A BRAHMS WALTZ plays.

What did you say? Allen turns the music up all the way. Allen mimes deafnes Finally, she understands: their sounds are drowned out by music. Allen reaches for her. She finally softens, takes his han As mother and son waltz together with the music, Naomi clutches Allen to her, like he's the only thing keeping h sane. Because he is.
Don't ever leave me. Allen, trapped, over her shoulder. From the doorway, we see that Louis has been watching the whole time.

Overwhelmed, Allen shakes on the front stairs. She's not well. The faint sound of jazz, fun from someone else's ho from down the block. Louis comes out onto the porch, with open LETTER in hand from the mail pile. He's upset.
Were you even going to tell me you applied?! Allen spies the "Columbia University" seal on the front. been caught. He looks down, ashamed.
I didn't want her to know. (beat) It was a dream anyway. Louis lights his own cigarette. Offers his son one. He declines.
(talking to himself, dreaming) Trilling's there. Van Doren. English Professors. Important fellows. And New York City, right in your goddamn lap. Louis sits beside his son.
Love that is hoarded, molds at last. Allen, surprised to hear his Dad reciting one of his poem
Until we know, the only thing we have--
is what we give away.
Is what we hand away. Have, hand. Consonance.
Give, is. Assonance.

I wrote the goddamn poem. Go write your own. Louis hands over the letter. The hardest thing he's ever done. Allen takes the envelope, rips it open. He's looking at t response in shock. Louis tries to read his son's face.
I got in.
You got in?!
I got into Columbia University!
You got into Columbia University?! Allen and his father embrace.
First day of college. Allen crosses the grand Ivy League campus in awe. Before him, the staggering facade of the library like the Parthenon. A troop of Navy midshipmen pa by. Wartime is on.

Allen sets his bag on his bed. He notices on one wall are patriotic posters, exercise posters. He's already got a roommate. He eyes a map of the New York City subway system. He can' believe he's really here in the big city. He walks over t it. Allen studies the map, his finger gliding down to Greenwi Village.
You don't wanna go down there. His roommate LUKE, 18, buzz cut, in a sweaty Columbia sweatshirt, leans over him.
Land of the fairies. Head there and you never come back. (extending a firm hand) Luke Detweiler, Danville, Virginia.
Allen Ginsberg.
(bright smile) You're Jewish, right? Allen nods. Luke smacks him on the shoulder.
I'm getting good at telling.

The beautiful main hall of Columbia University's Butler Library. It's Ivy League tradition meets thousands of yea of scholarship. A pompous TOUR GUIDE shows off museum-like glass vitrines new and prospective students with their families.
The South Hall library is a church, and these are the sacraments. Allen stumbles along on the tour. The tour guide points t the contents of the vitrines: the wonders of literary history.
Original folios of the most important texts in history. Beowolf. First folio Hamlet. The Gutenberg Bible. Allen looks down, amazed. That's Shakespeare's handwritin
These are among the University's most prized possessions. Suddenly, in a reflection in the glass, a flash of RED catches Allen's eye.

Let's hear a bit, shall we? Allen turns to see Lucien Carr (now 19, devilish, stunnin handsome) LEAP onto a library desk with a book in hand. H wears a distinctive red CRAVAT that only the truly beauti can pull off. The entire room hushes.
(reciting) On a Sunday afternoon, when the shutters are down and the proletariat possesses the street... The tour guide looks around confused.
...there are certain thoroughfares which remind one of nothing less... Lucien gets on his knees and THRUSTS a lamp between his l
...than a big cancerous cock. Parents look around in shock. A female student is instant aroused. The prim PERMISSIONS LIBRARIAN clomps over.
What is this nonsense?
Henry Miller.
Get down immediately. That book is restricted.
Which is why I committed it to memory.
Security! As two Campus Security Guards rush in, Lucien leaps down front of Allen.
Alert the press! Tell them Lucien Carr is innocent! Lucien flees, rushes out of the library.
That was highly unusual. Campus is actually quite quiet. Moving on. But Allen doesn't hear, he grins to himself. Who the hell that?
The Victorian sonnet has the balance of three tenets.
Patrician, old-guard PROFESSOR STEEVES lectures on the fi day of class, Allen dutifully taking notes in his journal
Rhyme, meter, conceit. Without this balance, a poem becomes slack, sloppy. An untucked shirt. Allen disagrees and raises his hand.
Professor Steeves, then how do you explain Whitman? No one interrupts Professor Steeves. Murmurs from around class. Steeves locks down his gaze on Allen.
Say more. Two more sentences.
He hated rhyme and meter. The whole point was untucking your shirt. Professor Steeves smiles to himself. There's one of them every year.
What's your name?
Allen Ginsberg.
Ginsberg? Your father perhaps is the poet Louis Ginsberg? Allen nods.
He writes rhyming, metered verse. Why do you think he chose that form? All eyes on Allen.
Because it's easier. The class titters. Professor Steeves hushes them.
This university exists because of tradition and form. Would you rather this building be built by engineers or Whitman and his boys at play?
Allen, realizing he is trapped, unable to answer. Profess Steeves smiles victoriously and writes on the blackboard.
There can be no creation before imitation. The other students take note. Allen sighs, follows suit. the back row, Lucien watches Allen and unsheathes a grin.
Luke, dressed in a suit, puts on cologne. He looks back a Allen who is copying from a tome of sonnets.
Shut the books. We're taking my brother with us to the social. He ships out tomorrow.
I can't. You see how much I've got to do.
He's Navy. It's catnip for the skirts. Luke pulls out his own waistband and sprays some cologne the front. Allen shakes his head. Luke shrugs.

You hymies are really all about work, huh? Luke slams the door behind. Allen, alone stares out the window. A record starts up down the hall. Clarinet, strings. Alle ears prick up. He knows this tune. It's the same BRAHMS from his mother's bedroom.
Allen walks down a darkened hallway, the music leading hi forward. He reaches a door with a lit transom. He knocks. The unlocked door creaks open.
A mattress lies on the floor, a phonograph on top. Candle light the room. Books for furniture. And Lucien on the fl reading the Times and smoking.
Brahms? Allen walks inside. Lucien looks up, surprised.
Finally. An oasis in this wasteland. Nervous, Allen tries to make conversation.
How come you're not at the social?
Only the most anti-social have to go to an event actually called one. Libation? Lucien rises and grabs a wine bottle corked with a sock. Allen looks nervously towards the door.
You drink in your room?!
How does a horrible bottle of Chianti sound? Lucien inverts two small glasses and pours. Allen stares. doesn't break the rules.
I don't drink.
Freshman?
Yes. Lucien hands him his glass.
Excellent. I love first times. I want my whole life to be composed of them. Life is only interesting if life is wide.
Lucien toasts Allen's glass.
To Walt Whitman, you dirty bastard. Allen, mortified, not sure how to take that reference as Lucien knocks his wine back in one gulp.
How's your Yeats? Have you read A Vision? He tosses Allen a BOOK. Dog-eared, underlined and crumbli
Never heard of it.

It's completely brilliant and impossible. He says life is round: we're stuck on this wheel. Living. And dying. Allen opens the book, looks through the old pages, sees a strange symbol: a diagram of a celestial WHEEL.
An endless circle. Until. Someone breaks it. You came in here, you rupture the pattern. Bang: the whole world...
Gets wider.                      Gets wider. Lucien looks at Allen, amazed.
How did you...?
Consonance. Reiteration of themes. Lucien, intrigued, circles in close.
Are you a writer? Because I've got a job for a writer. Allen, mesmerized.
No. I'm not.
Well, you're not anything yet. This boy so close, the rush of contact. From down the hal
Ginsberg?! Allen doesn't even register his name. Lucien smirks.
Isn't that you?
Ginsberg?! Allen groans, snaps out of it.
What?!
Phone call! Allen reluctantly hands Lucien back the BOOK.
I'll be back.
The Hall Monitor hands Allen the phone.
Hello?
I found the wires.
Naomi grips the phone desperately. We see she has strippe the wallpaper from the wall and pulled the telephone wire from underneath.
He's trying to get inside my head.
Dad is not trying to get inside your head, okay? Put him on.
He's not home. He left.
Allen, confused. Up the hallway, a door locks.
Where'd he go?
Naomi looks out the window, does not want to answer.
Honey, I need you come home now.
Mom I can't come home. Listen, you have to look after yourself.
I don't feel good.
Lucien passes Allen, putting on his coat, heading out to city.
(whispered, to Lucien) You're going to the dance?
No. Downtown.
Who are you talking to? Is he there with you?!
No, he's not here with me. Lucien quickly waves goodbye to Allen, heads down the staircase. Allen, torn between his mother and this boy.
(into the phone) Listen, I'll come as soon as I can.
Naomi, clutches the phone, deadly serious.
You need to promise.
Lucien slides down the stairway rail. Allen watching him disappear.
Yes. Ipromiseloveyoubye. Allen hangs up on his mother and races after Lucien.
Allen, breathless, storms down a flight of stairs, catche to Lucien. Lucien turns, loving this. The puppy following new master.
Coming?
Lucien throws his jacket over Allen's shoulder and leads into the wild city around the corner.

Welcome to the edge of the world. The sound of the IRT screeching takes us to the SUBWAY MA from Allen's dorm room which comes to life. A RED LINE glides down the map from Columbia University a the way...to Greenwich Village.
Allen, anxious, follows Lucien up a crowded staircase to West Village apartment. The sounds of a party spill out onto the landing and beyo It's pure bohemia here.

Smoke, artists flirting, arguing. Allen sees... A black man making out with a white woman. An older, eleg woman sharing a cigarette with a boy half her age. She stares seductively at Allen. Lucien enjoying himself immensely. This is what a first time looks like.
Allen in Wonderland. Lucien grabs a DRUNK YOUNG GIRL from the crowd, kisses he passionately. Then lets her go, keeps walking.
Do you know her?!
No, and I don't plan on it. She tasted like imported sophistication and domestic cigarettes.
A makeshift bar in a sink full of ice. Lucien scavenges through empty bottles in the sink, looking for any remain alcohol.
(calling out) Dave! Where's the liquor?! I'll be right back. As Lucien walks off, Allen tries to make himself inconspicuous and sits down on the tub.
Hrffrff hrffrfffrfrfrrf. Allen looks down to see WILLIAM BURROUGHS (aka BILL, 29, tall, gaunt, wry), in a suit, sprawled out in the bathtub gas mask over his mouth. Bill motions to the side of the
(through the mask) You're...pinching... Allen stands up, realizing his foot is on a snaking black tube leading to a metal canister of gas.
Sorry. Are you all right?
(long exhale) Artifacts in the visual field, some light-headedness. Motor hyperactivity.
What is that?
Nitrous oxide, for narcoanalysis. Know thyself. And beshit thyself. Ever done that? Allen shakes his head no. Bill turns off the gas. Offers joint to Allen.
Oh no, thanks. I don't do...the cannabis. Bill eyes Allen, skeptically.
Show me the man both sober and happy, and I'll show you the crinkled anus of a lying asshole. Allen raises an eyebrow. Lucien returns with a paper in h
Allen, Willy. Willy, Allen, Lucien reefer. Lucien takes the joint. Bill puts the tube of gas back in his mouth, back to business. Lucien grabs Allen's hand, pulls him to the par
(whispered) Is he a criminal?
He wishes he were a criminal. The Burroughs family is richer than God.
He looks like a criminal.
He's a Harvard man, and he's going to be an amazing artist. His current medium is himself. Allen spots the TERM PAPER in Lucien's hand.
What's that?
Bunk for school. Now, come on, I want you to meet our host.
DAVID KAMMERER, the man we saw dead at the film's opening runs his fingers on the rim of a wine glass. He's sharp, mayor of this scene. An eerie hum from the glass.
What there is, darlings and demoiselles, is a circle. Life is round. Patterns, routines, a wheel of self-abuse. Margaret, don't even deny it. Allen turns to Lucien.
(whispered) Sounds like you.
Because it was me. First. David sees the boys talking. He eyes Allen, curiously.
Until. The the disruption we long for, comes along and the circle is broken.
(whispered, to Allen) He said he was my guardian angel, but that I was too much work. David crosses through crowd towards Allen.
Take this unbloomed stalwart.
Uh-oh. Allen's singled out. David pulls him to the center the room.
And you are?
Allen. Bill walks in, knows what game his friend is playing.
Play nice, David.
Allen, who comes uninvited to my apartment.
Actually I invited him.
None of us notice him. Look at him. Why would we bother? In his tucked shirt and creased pants, Allen realizes the entire party is scrutinizing, judging him.

So the pattern of our evening, our lives, holds. But under the right circumstances, even he might change the world. Jazz music sparks, PRE-LAP from where this party's going next. Lucien eyes Allen -- an idea forming.
The party continuing at this underground speakeasy. Strai gay, young, old, a subterranean zoo. A jazz signer owns t room. Bill, David, and Allen at a table. David's moment alone w Allen.
So you just met Lucien in the lunch line and now he's all that you can see.
Why don't you like me?
Because David was in the same godforsaken line. David and Bill share a knowing look. Lucien returns to th table and slams a glass down.
Some earjob at the bar just called me "boy." So I stole his drink. Allen scans, sees the famous poet OGDEN NASH looking arou for his glass.
That's Ogden Nash!
Who's Ogden Nash?
The best selling poet in the country.
"A girl who is bespectacled. She may not get her nectacled. But safety pins and bassinets--"
"Await the girl who fassinets."
And that's what he's selling?! I'll kill him. Bill takes out a switchblade.
Aim for the throat. A realization. Lucien leans in, focuses his charm.
No. We're not going to kill him. Even better. We're going make sure nobody remembers him. (turns to Allen) How many men started the Renaissance?
Two.
And the Romantics.
More than I suspect this theory accommodates.
(Five?) Lucien's passion building.
We're sending millions to fight the Fascists in Europe, but they're here! Meter and rhyme---
And Professor Steeves---
Yes! They're all guards in some prison. Let's make the prisoners come out and play. Let's come up with new words, new rhythms. Allen, swept up in the energy. He couldn't be more captivated.
We need a name.
How did they come up "Dada"?
Tristan Tzara jabbed a knife into a dictionary.
Shit. So that's been done.
A literary revolution without writing a word. Neat trick, Lu.
Well, I'm listening.
What about Yeats? How about the "New Vision?"

Ginsy, you're hired! Allen smiles a mile wide. He's in. Suddenly, the jazz singer stops. The band puts down their instruments. POLICEMEN escort a businessman and another gentleman out of the bathroom, in HANDCUFFS. The mood in bar chills.
Fucking perverts. Allen, terrified, looks at David, who looks back, knowing exactly now who Allen is. A DOOR CRASH leads us to...
Drunk, Allen and Lucien stumble to the ground.
"In the dawn, armed with a burning patience, we shall enter the splendid city!" Allen sits up.
Shit.
It's Rimbaud. It's overwritten, I know. He's allowed.
No, my mother. This is bad. This is very bad.
What is? Allen stands, gathers himself urgently. He needs to be somewhere about twelve hours ago.
She's going to be furious.
Don't go then.
You don't understand. I have to.
What?
It's complicated. Lucien sees his friend scared. Moved, he links his arm wi Allen's.
Perfect. I love complicated.
Allen and Lucien enter the house to find Louis standing nervously with a suitcase beside a DOCTOR.
Greystone will alert you if there's a change in her condition. A DOCTOR holds out a clipboard. Louis sheepishly signs th document on top.
Dad, what's going on?
Your mother needs her rest. A male nurse leads Naomi from the bedroom. She is still i her robe, shattered and fogged by sedatives. Allen realiz what's happening.
(to his father) You can't do this to her. Naomi recognizes her son.
Where were you?
I was out. With a friend.
I called you!
It's time to go, Mrs. Ginsberg. The nurse takes Naomi to the door. Allen pulls her back, the house.
No, you're not leaving. Naomi points an accusing finger at Louis.
He already signed the papers.
Dad?!
It's for the best.
Your best.
It's for her best. It's not for my best. Look at her! Listen to her! Naomi babbling. Allen realizing how far she's gone. Allen shoves the nurse off Naomi.
Get off! From deep within, Allen can see she is still there, and w can see she knows that it's too late.
This is your fault. The nurse escorts a docile Naomi out of the room. Allen breaks down. Lucien, mute witness to it all. MUSIC PLAYS over...
Louis lectures Allen. We close in on Allen's despondent face. The dutiful son's first failure.
Allen escapes outside where Lucien is sitting, smoking. A sits beside him, notices: Lucien has been crying.
Complicated enough?
At least you have her. My father left me when I was four. A beat of understanding between them. Lucien lays down. A takes his cigarette, lays next to him.
I've been thinking about what Yeats said. To be reborn, we have to die first. Allen hands him back the smoke. Lucien perks up.
So what do you suggest?
Candlelight flickers on Allen's face.
I've spent my life making other people happy. We PULL BACK to see a noose around Allen's neck. A suicid underway.
It's time I find happiness the only way I see possible.
Oh please. Die already. We PULL BACK again to see Lucien beside, also with a noos around his neck. Both of them on chairs. Their nooses are attached to the same pipe.
Where's the verve? The brio?! From atop the chair, Lucien kicks his record player with foot. Grand classical music screeches to a start.
If it be that I am indulging my self-consciousness in justifying myself, or if it be--
That's a run-on.

Don't edit me! Lucien shoves Allen. Allen trips off the chair, the noose snaps tight...and suddenly he's hanging in mid-air. He struggles. Lucien tries to help, but falls off his own ch The pipe starts to bend. Allen and Lucien panic as they swing through the room, suspended in air. The pipe BREAKS. They crash to the ground. A beat of relief -- are we alive? -- and the two break ou into hysterics. DIRTY BE-BOP JAZZ PLAYS OVER...

head_text.subj: A RED LINE TRAVELS UP THE SUBWAY MAP FROM COLUMBIA UNIVER

text: The black crowd claps for the same jazz singer and band w saw earlier, now on their home turf. Allen, Lucien and Bi watch from a table.
The New Vision declares--
"Proclaims" is better--
Lucien and Allen pace while Bill reclines on the sofa. Th riff on the The New Vision manifesto.
Proclaims the death of morality. And...
The expression of self.
The true, uninhibited, uncensored expression of the self.
Words, boys. Empty words.
Then what do you suggest?
The derangement of the senses.
Allen bopping his head to the new rhythms in this club - place where be-bop jazz is being born.
Bill cracking open a Benzedrine canister and removing the soaking strip from inside. He drops it into three coffee cups. The boys knock it bac Lucien pushing Allen to finish the whole drink.
Allen furiously typing up the manifesto at his school des
What do you hate from the pit of your gut?
Allen, Lucien pacing with increasing excitement.
Institutions.
Paterson, New Jersey.
My father. Bill smiles. They're playing his game.
Bingo. The music suddenly stops as we ...
Professor Steeves lecturing before the class.
And so while Shakespeare... He notices Allen's empty seat. Unhappy.
All right. The MUSIC builds again as...
...a drummer takes a wild solo. Enraptured, Allen taps hi fingers to these new rhythms.
Allen's fingers typing in these same rhythms. Beside, The Yorker advertising Ogden Nash's upcoming reading.
Extraordinary men propel society forward. It is our duty to break the law.
Allen stopping Lucien in his tracks.
Really?
It's how we make the world wider. Allen considers, agrees.
You are an extraordinary man. Lucien beams.
Well, thank you.
Bill at David's bookcase, removing classic art and litera books and throwing them to Allen.

"Return of the Native." "Leviathan." Tear `em up boys. Destroy the old and build the new! Allen, with scissors, cuts up pages of the books. Hands t to Lucien who nails them to the wall. It's a frantic assembly-line: Bill whips books to Allen, Allen tears out sections, and Lucien hammers them up. We PULL BACK to see the entire wall is covered in words.

Time suddenly slows. The music tapers, the hands of the drummer taper down to a still. Allen looks around, scared confused. What is happening? A spotlight cuts through the room, capturing the singer's sweaty ecstasy, the bassist's fingers mid-plucking. The r freezes. Unlit cigarette dangling from his lip, Allen turns to Bil

Bill holds up his finger - it is on fire. He lights Allen cigarette with the flame. We have entered into another universe. Lucien stands -- the only thing moving -- and Allen follo He steps into the frozen moment. And it's beautiful.
Watch this. Lucien leans over a young woman, a statue at a table with young man in military attire.

(whispered in her ear) Go. The girl comes to life and clambers over the young man to second, more attractive soldier. And kisses him. The pair erupt into life, into desire. Lucien and Allen sit on the stage beneath the frozen musicians. Lucien pulls out a BOY SCOUT KNIFE. Wraps Allen's hand in a fist around the blade. He pulls the knife free. Allen winces in pain. Lucien does the same to his own palm, then presses their bloody hands together. A ceremony. Allen's eyes roll back David appears in a janitor uniform. The Technicolor fades
What the hell is this?
Allen, the nitrous oxide mask over his face inhaling from tank of gas. He has been adrift in a hallucination. Lucien presses Allen's hand back and forth, both unharmed
Time slows down as you drift deeper and deeper into your cave... Bill notices David, turns off the gas.
We are exploring the avenues of Allen's mind. David looks around the mess of his living room, his pilla library of books, papers all over the floor.
Dimly-lit, I am sure. What have you done to my apartment? Allen struggles to his feet, moaning. Lucien steps betwee David and their wall of clippings.
David, don't touch anything. We have to write it all down. Bill stands up, woozy. Calls out to David.
Get this man a pair of scissors!
This is not your revolution, this is my life.
What kind of life is it?
It's mine. Not everyone gets an allowance. (beat) Leave. Get out! Allen stumbles out of the room, scared. David approaches Lucien.
I need to speak to you. Alone.
Allen splashes water on his face. In the mirror, he sees David and Lucien in the bedroom. David hands Lucien a TERM PAPER.
It only has to be five pages.
He tilts the mirror to see them clearly. A glimpse into t private dynamic.
Lucien flips through the term paper.
You make me too smart, they're gonna suspect something's up. David throws Lucien's coat over his shoulder.
And get you sent back to your mother again? That would just be the end of you.
Fuck you. David spots Allen watching from the bathroom.
Allen, caught, looks down, pretends he heard nothing. But it's too late. David walks over and SLAMS the door in All face.
Kill your darlings.
Professor Steeves, intent, in front of the class.

Your crushes, your juvenile metaphysics. None of them belong on the page. It is the first principle of good creative work. A work of fiction you will deliver as your final exam. He sees Allen, badly hungover and brooding, writing in a journal. Ignoring class.
Oh look. Whitman Jr. graced us with his presence today.
Steeves walks to Allen's desk, grabs his journal.
"The New Vision. Extraordinary men propel us forward. It is our duty to break the law." (to Allen) Fantastic.
There's more life in those five pages than in the dozens of bad sonnets we've read in class. Steeves cocks his eye, stares down Allen. The first time Allen has defied anyone. Ever.
You want life? You want the world on fire? Steeves motions to the door. Then to Allen.
The war awaits. What will it be? Steeves tosses the journal back down on Allen's desk. Allen looks down at the "New Vision", ashamed.
A rainstorm beating against the windows. Allen paces as a drunk Lucien knocks off a bottle of wine and reads from Allen's journal.
"The rose that scents the summer air/ grows from my beloved's hair...?"
Keep going. That's my sonnet for Steeves. Lucien flips through the journal, closes it, disappointed
We have the map. We have the manifesto. We need the work. (suddenly cold) I was wrong. Maybe you're not up for this after all.
Allen stares at Lucien in disbelief. Shocked, Allen rushe Lucien's desk.
Show me your fucking map.
Stop! Allen grabs the pages Lucien has been working on: they ar covered in doodles - there's nothing there.

What kind of sick son of a bitch would do something like this? LUCIEN
It was David. JACK
I'll wring his fucking neck. LUCIEN's P.O.V.: Jack's Merchant Marine duffel bag that E has fully packed for him. LUCIEN
I have another idea.

Allen sits at a table at the library he just broke into a robbed. But now he's just another student sitting at a st desk. He puts in a blank page in the typewriter before him and types: "On The Decline of the West. By..." He hesitates, breaking down in tears. Then finishes typing: "Lucien Carr."
Lucien, in a Merchant Marine uniform, packs his clothes i a sailor's duffel bag. Allen enters, type-written pages i hand. ALLEN
Your paper and my apology. Allen hands Lucien the paper he wrote for him. But Lucien doesn't take it. Allen registers that he's packing. ALLEN
Where are you going? LUCIEN
Sailing out. To Paris. Lucien grabs his BOY-SCOUT KNIFE. Puts it in his pocket. Allen is speechless.
LUCIEN
We've got to make a ship, probably as merchant seamen. Jack knows the tricks. ALLEN
You weren't going to tell me? LUCIEN
We both know why you can't come. Silence. Lucien continues his packing. Allen breaks down. ALLEN
Fuck you. You're a phony. You got me and Jack and Bill making your vision come true. All because you couldn't do it yourself. LUCIEN

No, you got what you wanted. You were ordinary, just like every other freshman, and I made your life extraordinary. Go be you now, all by yourself. Leave me alone. Allen, now in tears, realizing the end is here. ALLEN
You don't really mean that. LUCIEN
(cold, deadened) Allen. Leave. Allen gathers himself, stumbles out the door. Leaving the friendship behind. Alone, Lucien cracks, breaking down as he closes his suitcase.
Allen crosses through the courtyard, heading to class. He comes upon David, waiting for Lucien. Pale. Distraught. DAVID
Allen, have you seen him? He's not in his room. They look almost the same.
ALLEN
He left. DAVID
I did something wrong. Really wrong. And you have no reason to help me. But ALLEN
But? DAVID
I know who you are. We're the ones he needs, but never wants. It hurts, doesn't it? Allen burns, does not respond. David is right. DAVID
All I am asking is tell me where he is. Please. CLOSE ON: Allen, on the blade of a choice.
Jack and Lucien in a long line of young soldiers waiting ship out. Lucien nips at a flask. They reach the front of line. A BILLETING OFFICER calls out to them. BILLETING OFFICER
Lemme see your papers. LUCIEN
Two seamen, reporting for duty. Jack tries not to laugh, hands over his paperwork. The officer points to Lucien. BILLETING OFFICER
What's your name? LUCIEN
Arthur Rimbaud. Jack rolls his eyes. The officer hands the paperwork back BILLETING OFFICER
Go upstairs to get on the docket. LUCIEN
Let's go get on the docket.
As they turn to leave, they see David is there, descendin the stairs. Jack is about to pounce. JACK
Goddamn son of a bitch! LUCIEN
Let me handle this. Lucien holds Jack back, rushes up to David. LUCIEN
How did you know I would be here?! DAVID
Listen, I spoke to a guy upstairs. I got two passes. I packed for both of us. We can leave. LUCIEN
The reason I'm leaving is you. It doesn't register. Desperate, David holds out the passe DAVID
Then you and Jack take them. I'll catch up. Lucien considers this, then makes a fateful decision. LUCIEN
Come with me. We're taking a walk.
Allen, wrecked, walks into the bar where he first drank w Lucien. He sees an older man eyeing him and sits down, terrified. ALLEN
Could I have a whiskey, please?
Jack unlocks his door. Edie sits on the floor, her eyes r from crying. Jack drops his duffel bag. Sits with her. JACK
I'm sorry. Edie embraces him.
Allen sees a young man in a Merchant Marine outfit, blond the bar lamps casting a golden halo around his head. Coul be? ALLEN
Lu? Allen races to him. The man turns and Allen's heart sinks is a SAILOR, a distant echo of Lucien. The Sailor eyes Allen gently, seductively. Allen walks up to him.
Edie breaks the embrace. EDIE
This came for you today. She hands Jack a package from the mail. A new record. JACK
Sammy... Jack places it on the record player and listens, clutchin Edie. He knows immediately there won't be another record. SAMMY (V.O.)
Jack, old chum. I'm on a hospital ship now. My guts all tore up.
Allen undresses, terrified, as the sailor does the same. SAMMY (V.O.)
Anzio's going to be the last place I ever see with my eyes.
Bill with Norman, his dealer, in his apartment. Norman injects himself with a morphine syrette. Bill watches, fascinated.
SAMMY (V.O.)
A mortar round came and found me in my tent. Norman offers the box of morphine to Bill. Bill handles i Considering.
Lucien walks, guzzles from his flask. David follows. They visibly arguing. SAMMY (V.O.)
I can feel metal under my skin some places. Some went clean through.
Jack continues to listen to Sammy, his heart sinking. He knows this is headed to a dark place. SAMMY (V.O.)
They're not even trying to take it out no more.
Allen's heart in his throat as he steps out of his pants. is nearly naked. Vulnerable.
Lucien throws his flask into the woods, LASHES out at Dav
Bill injects the syrette into his wrist. And presses the oblivion in. SAMMY (V.O.)
The nurses gave me the same morphine I gave to dying boys...
Allen, naked, lays on the bed. He turns off the light.
SAMMY (V.O.)
...when I didn't know what else to do. The sailor climbs on top of Allen, turns it back on.
David LUNGES for Lucien and Lucien throws him off, spins away. He pulls out his Boy Scout knife. David stares at Lucien, stunned.
Allen turns to face the sailor. Looks him in the eye. SAMMY (V.O.)
Wake, melancholy mother. Wake and weep. Allen reaches to kiss the sailor.
Lucien STABS David, plunges the blade into his chest.
The sailor enters Allen.
Bill drifts backwards, into the high. SAMMY (V.O.)
Quench within thy burning bed, thy fiery tears.
David looks up from his chest. Blood pumps from the gash. David, clutching his shirt, his chest...
SAMMY (V.O.)
And let thy loud heart keep-- The record runs out, the stylus scratches. Jack, tremblin EDIE
What is that? JACK
It's Shelley's elegy for Keats. EDIE
What's that mean? JACK
It means he's dead.
FADE UP ON: Allen, alone in the shower. He's completely blank, eyes on the tile. Realizing what he did the night before and how it felt so natural -- now he knows exactly who he is.
Allen steps out in a bathrobe, to see a POLICEMAN and a DETECTIVE whispering outside Lucien's room. POLICEMAN
He didn't come back here afterwards. Nobody on the floor saw. They stare at Allen, studying him. Other students whisper POLICEMAN
We have two in custody. We're still getting names. Allen makes his way down the hall. Custody? What happened Lucien? DETECTIVE
So what do we know about this Carr kid? Did we have any friends? We're gonna have to speak to all of them.
Allen looks down and races to the hallway phone.
Allen dials a number. Nervous. Edie picks up. ALLEN
Edie? Is Jack there? EDIE (O.S.)
You don't know? ALLEN
Know what?
Edie searches for the words. EDIE
The police took him down to the Tombs. As an accessory. Bill too. ALLEN (O.S.)
What happened? Edie shocked, unable to speak.

The BLARE of a prison horn. A guard opens a heavy gate an Allen walks onto the hall of cells. It's a long, dank wal Allen spots Lucien in a small unremarkable cell, behind b reading. Allen can't believe he's here. Lucien sits up from his cot and rushes to the bars. LUCIEN
Allen, thank God. Allen's skeptical face makes Lucien change tactics. ALLEN
How could you? LUCIEN
He wanted to hurt me, I had no choice.
ALLEN
You could have run. Called the police. Lucien looks Allen fiercely in the eye. LUCIEN
Listen. Somehow he found me at the Marine Hall. Allen looks away, realizing he is potentially complicit. LUCIEN
He said no matter where I went, he would follow. When I confronted him, he exploded. I had to defend myself. He wouldn't stop. ALLEN
But how did Jack and Bill get roped into this?
Lucien drops the bloody Boy Scout knife down a grate. Jac stands guard. LUCIEN (O.S.)
I went to Jack first. He told me to get rid of the knife. To forget the whole thing. They hear footsteps and turn. A black woman watches them suspiciously.
LUCIEN (O.S.)
But then I went to Bill. He told me to get a lawyer. Bill fingering David's pack of Lucky Strikes in his bathr David's blood on his hand. LUCIEN (O.S.)
To say it was an act of self- defense. Lucien watches Bill light one of the bloody cigarettes an inhale. The last flare of his friend.
Bill flushes the rest of the pack down the toilet.
Lucien, desperate, at the bars of his cell. LUCIEN
The D.A. is asking for my deposition. In writing. Allen shakes his head, there's no way he's going to do th LUCIEN

(pleading) We both know I can't do it. I don't know what I'm going to do. I'm going to be stuck in here for the rest of my life! Allen, still unsure. Lucien slides his hand down the bars until it touches Allen's. Pleads seductively. LUCIEN
Please don't leave me here. The BUZZER goes off. Visiting time is over. The prison gu heads towards the cell. Allen makes a fateful choice. ALLEN
I'll do it. Lucien, smiling. Leans in, whispers. LUCIEN
We're going to say it was an "honor slaying". Off Allen's confused face...
A finger traces down a legal index to the definition of t phrase: "Honor Slaying." ALLEN (V.O.)
"Related to a lethal attack committed when the accused is defending himself against a known homosexual."
OTHER students around Allen gossip and steal glances at h as he reads to himself from the index. The murderer's "friend." ALLEN (V.O.)
"If the accused is heterosexual, he shall be pardoned. But if the accused is homosexual, the charge of murder in the first degree..." Allen's attention falls to the final words:
Jack, in handcuffs, on the phone. PHOTOGRAPHERS, JOURNALI outside, clamoring for Jack to look their way. A murder w Columbia University students, this is big news. JACK
Dad. It's five thousand dollars for bail. I know it's a lot-- A flash bulb FIRES. Journalists cat-calling for Jack's attention. JACK'S FATHER (O.S.)
No Kerouac was ever wrapped up in a murder! Go to hell. The line goes dead. Jack has run out of options. More flashbulbs EXPLODE. More screaming for his attention. Jac whips around. JACK
Would you all just SHUT THE HELL
Marion Carr taking down Lucien's dorm room, packing her s belongings into the same suitcase he tried to run away wi before. MARION CARR
You must understand David has been following him for years. Allen, smoking nervously from Lucien's bed, watching all traces of Lucien being torn down.
MARION CARR

When Lucien went to Bowdoin, David appeared out of thin air. So I sent Lu to Chicago. Allen registers the reference from Lucien's conversation the Dean, a dim clue. Marion goes back to packing. MARION CARR
Surprise, David turned up there too. Then, when Lucien wanted to go to Mexico, guess who had a car idling in the driveway? ALLEN
But he didn't have to go with him. MARION CARR
He spun a web to ensnare my son. That's why I brought him here. A lot of good that did. Marion finds Lucien's cravat, quickly folds it, hides it the suitcase. Allen notices. ALLEN
What happened in Chicago? Marion stops packing. Thinks. She settles on the bed, cha Allen with a smile. MARION CARR
Thank God Lu has you in his life. He talks about you all the time. She leans over and slips the cigarette from Allen's hands into her own. Inhales seductively. MARION CARR
You know what Allen? He calls you his guardian angel. ALLEN
That's what he called David. She exhales, her face falls. Leans in threateningly. MARION CARR
That man ruined my son. You're going to help me keep what's left of him.
The zip of a suitcase. Bill, undoing his den, packing awa clothes, books. He's also leaving town. Allen's come for answers --- from the only person who knew the real David. BILL
Contrary to reports, prison is not a tonic for the spirit. We are now realizing it's the end of a chapter for all of them. BILL
All the district attorney cared about was if David was queer. Allen gulps. The heart of the issue, thrust into the ligh ALLEN
And what did you tell them? Bill sees the box of morphine from his night with Norman. decides to take it with him, hides it under a pile of shi BILL
I said yes. ALLEN
Did David do something Lu in Chicago? BILL
Christ Allen, please don't get involved. ALLEN
I have to be. I'm helping him write his defense. Bill paces, then turns to face Allen. BILL
David was my friend. But he's dead. And did Lucien tell you how he died? Allen shakes his head. He has no idea.

The moment right after Lucien stabbed David. What we have seen yet. The story continues. David trembles on the ground, bleeding from the knife wou Lucien stands above, realizing what just happened. Car headlamps swipe across Lucien's face. Terrified, Luci scans the park for witnesses. BILL (O.S.)

He might not have wanted you to know, Allen. He tied David up. Lucien DRAGS David's body from the park under a railing t the shoreline. He unties his shoes, LASHES David's hands together with t shoelaces. Ties them tight. David groans and gurgles blood. Still very much ALIVE. Lucien rustles through David's pockets -- pulls out anyth side. He tosses David's pack of Lucky Strike cigarettes, speckled with blood - to the sand. Lucien collects stones from the riverbank, STUFFS them in David's pockets. BILL (O.S.)

He put stones in his pockets to weigh him down. Lucien panics, looks around. He takes off his Merchant Ma clothes. Fully naked, he drags a bound David into the dar waters of the Hudson River. David moans and struggles but is no match for Lucien. BILL (O.S.)
And dragged him into the Hudson River. ALLEN (O.S.)
What?! BILL (O.S.)
David was alive, Allen, until Lucien made him drown. The sound of a door slamming open brings us...
MR. BURROUGHS (60s, patrician, wealthy), Bill's father en his son's apartment, causing Bill to stop telling the sto Mr. Burroughs eyes Allen suspiciously. MR. BURROUGHS
Who are you? Is he part of this business. BILL
Leave him alone, Dad. MR. BURROUGHS
I paid your bail. Don't talk to me like that. Bill looks down, obedient. The rebel silenced by his fath BILL
Yes, sir. MR. BURROUGHS
The car leaves in five minutes. As Mr. Burroughs exits, Bill furiously SLAMS his suitcase closed. BILL
The libertine circle has come to an end. Allen looks at Bill, lost at what to do next. Bill leans close. BILL
Go back to the beginning.

head_text.subj: THE RED LINE LEADS US, ONCE MORE, DOWN THE SUBWAY MAP FRO
TO THE EDGE OF THE WORLD. WHERE IT ALL STARTED.

text: The window bangs open. Allen climbs into David's apartmen from the fire-escape. He opens the door to the living room. Sunlight filtering a dusty, silent apartment.
It is eerie. The place of someone who just left the world Allen looks around, unsure what he's looking for. His eyes fall on the bookshelves. Memories flood back, raveling and unraveling.

Books LEAP into Bill's hands and he places them back on t shelves. Allen UNSUTURES the pages of books, returning back to the original condition. Lucien TAP nails out of the wall handing the pages back t Allen. Allen scouring his memories, just like when he wrote his earlier. Time runs in reverse.

Allen searches through the steamer trunk of the apartment Nothing. He ruffles through the console table. Again noth He notices David's SUITCASE. The one David packed before planning on leaving by boat with Lucien. Allen opens it. He digs through it, searching for some cl any clue -- something to shed light on the past. He pulls out a pile of clothes and underneath them...a bo It's a copy of Yeats' A VISION, covered in notes. It's David's. It's the same edition of the copy that Lucien showed Alle his room.

Time shifts into reverse -- we realize this Allen's mind work: rummaging for details, clues, snatches of life. We see the first night Allen met David -- David circling finger around his wineglass, his speech about life as a circle,slipping through time...

Allen opening the book to find the legend that Lucien onc showed him, the picture of Yeats's WHEEL. A stack of PAPERS fall from the book. Allen rifles throug them. And finds a faded pink hospital "ADMIT" form. Cook County Hospital, Chicago. March 1943. He scans down the page: "Carr, Lucien. Suicide Attempt. G Inhalation. Admitting Person: D. Kammerer." At the bottom, the form reads "Next of Kin." Beside is the name: David Kammerer. Below, Allen sees POSTCARDS, PHOTOS. Photos of the beach, Lucien and David, reclining together. It's their trip to Mexico. In photo, the two of them, posing for the camera together Smiling. Looking very much like a couple in love. Lucien's signature red CRAVAT hangs around David's neck. On the backside, written by hand is: LUCIEN (V.O.)
The perfect day. Allen, shocked. The puzzle pieces have fallen into place.
INSERT: A photo of Lucien in The New York Times.
The headline: "STUDENT IS SILENT ON SLAYING FRIEND. HELD

The sound of footsteps. Allen looks over the article. He's on a bench in the hall of an old sanitarium. His mother, Naomi, approaches, tentatively. The first tim they have seen each other since she was taken from home. Both of them scared to make the first move towards re- connection. Naomi steps towards her son, takes his face in her hands. Allen melts in her arms.
Allen and Naomi, in the courtyard of the hospital. Patien being led through the sanitarium's gardens by nurses behi Naomi, looks remarkably more calm then the last time Alle saw her. NAOMI
He would leave me alone in the house. I was going to die there. ALLEN
No, Mom. That's not true. NAOMI
Yeah, I know it. Naomi sinks inside herself, dark thoughts returning. ALLEN
Mom, stop. NAOMI
Hey, I'm okay now. I'm your mother. And I'm okay. She notices the bags under his eyes. His weary face. NAOMI
But you're not. Allen, a kid out of his league.
ALLEN
I'm in over my head. Someone I know killed a man. And I don't know what to do. He wants my help. And I don't know if I should give it to him. I don't know if it's right. It's just a mess. NAOMI
Let him go. Don't help him. ALLEN
I can't, mom. He's my best friend. NAOMI
Listen to me. Naomi pulls her son closer. With more strength than she h displayed in years. NAOMI
The most important thing your father ever did was fail me. (beat) You understand? Allen, realizing what he has to do.

Late night. Allen, back at the typewriter where he wrote poem for Lucien. He inserts a blank page. The task before him feels huge. The events of the night in question -- the night of David murder -- ravels and unravels in his mind's eye.
David, stabbed, gasping at Lucien with horror. The knife being pulled back, the wound closing back up.
David, reaching for Lucien, in reverse, Lucien walking ba to David, ending in an embrace. ALLEN (V.O.)
He loved you. And the truth is, once--
Allen turns over the old PHOTOGRAPH of David and Lucien together from David's apartment. The Perfect Day. ALLEN (V.O.)
You loved him back.

Time now runs forward, to the inevitable. We watch Lucien David walking once more of the night of the murder. But t time we hear their argument. Lucien, drunk, tosses his fl into the bushes. David follows him, desperate. DAVID
Let's get out of the city. Anywhere you want. I've saved up. ALLEN (V.O.)
But this secret ate away at you. LUCIEN
I was just a kid, you dragged me into your perverted mess! ALLEN (V.O.)
So in Chicago, you tried to kill yourself. DAVID
How can you say that? You know that's not true. Lucien stops short. Stares hard at David. DAVID
I will never give up on us. ALLEN (V.O.)
He rescued you. He saved your life. LUCIEN
You're pathetic. Lucien walks on, but David lunges for him. They struggle. Lucien throws David off, spins free from his grasp, pulls his Boy Scout knife from his pocket. The two men face each other.
ALLEN (V.O.)
You needed him as much as he needed you. The bare blade FLASHES between them. David, looking at th knife, shocked that their relationship has come to this. looks back up at Lucien. DAVID
Now I know how you felt. LUCIEN
When? DAVID
When you wanted to die. David takes a step, closing the gap between him and the knife. Daring Lucien to strike. DAVID

Do it. Lucien moves forward. The gap narrows. Just inches away f each other. David steps forward onto the blade. Lucien does not back David gasps, notices the knife deep in his chest to the h Blood pumps from the gash. Lucien frees the knife. Then pulls back and STABS David a second time. With malice. And again. Plunges the blade into his chest. He grinds th knife into David even further.. DAVID
Oh my god... David DROPS, clutching his shirt, his life pulsing from h chest.
Allen writing madly. The words come in a rush.
ALLEN (V.O.)
Some things once you love them become yours forever.
Out in the Hudson River, Lucien cradles David's dying bod his arms. David looks up at Lucien, his last moment of li The opening shot of the film. ALLEN (V.O.)
And if you try to let them go... David's eyes CLOSE. Lucien releases David out into the current. ALLEN (V.O.)
...they only circle back and return to you. David sinks into the depths of the Hudson, becoming just shadow then disappearing altogether. ALLEN (V.O.)
They become part of who you are.
From his cell, Lucien Carr finishes reading Allen's DEPOSITION. LUCIEN
Or they destroy you. We have returned to the opening scene of the movie. Lucie crumples the paper in his hand. LUCIEN
You can't show this to anyone. Allen stares at Lucien defiantly through the bars. ALLEN
Then tell the truth, Lu. LUCIEN
You weren't even there. It's your truth. It's fiction.
Allen grabs for the manuscript. Lucien pulls it out of re LUCIEN
You wanted him gone too. You sent him to me. Allen SNATCHES the manuscript -- it's a tug of war throug the bars. LUCIEN (CONT'D)
Please. You'll kill me with that. Allen yanks the paper from Lucien's grip. He heads toward the exit of the prison. Desperate, Lucien calls out after him. LUCIEN
Allen! No! DON'T! An alarm HAMMERS through the prison, sending us to...
The New York City's District Attorney's SECRETARY at her reception desk. Allen enters the room, his deposition in hand. He is visibly nervous as he approaches the desk. ALLEN
Allen Ginsberg. SECRETARY
He'll be with you in a minute. Please, have a seat. Allen waits, glances at the deposition in his lap. The ti reads, "The Night in Question."
From his prison bed, Lucien stares down the cellblock, hopeless. His eyes alight on his sheets.
The camera moves in an arc, rotating past Allen, sweating toward the door of the DISTRICT ATTORNEY...
...the same circle finds Lucien as he RIPS the bedsheet i strips. Frantic...
The circle discovers Allen, unable to sit still. The weig of his decision crushes him...
...Lucien fashions a noose around his neck. He ties the s to one of the cell bars. We glide past him back to...
...Allen spies the shadow of the District Attorney behind frosted glass of his office...

...the circling suddenly STOPS at Lucien as the knot on t noose catches. He is hanging, choking, desperate to die a yet fighting for life. But the knot on the cell bars releases. Lucien FALLS to t ground. Alive.
The secretary hangs up the phone. SECRETARY
Mr. Ginsberg. He's ready for you. She looks at the chair. No one is there. SECRETARY
Mr. Ginsberg? The sound of the door closing. Allen is gone. MALE VOICE (O.S.)
How did you expect us to react to this?

Allen's manuscript HITS the Dean's desk. The deposition's title page now reads "The Night in Quest by Allen Ginsberg." It's been refashioned into a novella. Allen sits in the same chair where Lucien was reprimanded Professor Steeves sits silently beside the Dean at his de DEAN
No, please tell me. Professor Steeves says you submitted it as your final. Allen, nervous in the chair. DEAN
Well, then, let me tell you. It is smutty and absurd. ALLEN
But you finished it. The Dean loses his patience. DEAN

You've taken incompletes in two classes. And you are already on academic probation. There are rules you agreed to upon admittance into this university. And you have managed to break and keep breaking them. You don't seem to have much respect for this institution. So you may either retract this fiction as your final. Or you may choose to be expelled. What will it be? Professor Steeves eyes Allen. ALLEN
Fine. Allen stands, making his decision. ALLEN
Consider me expelled. Allen reaches for his manuscript. The Dean SLIDES it out reach. DEAN
This remains with us.
Professor Steeves keeps a close eye on Allen as he leaves office.

Back in the Ginsberg residence, but the house is quiet no peaceful. No Naomi. The radio playing softly in the livin room. Louis jotting down verse on the back of the mail. Allen, shirt untucked, composing a poem on the back of a bill. They both reach for their cigarettes at the same time. Louis looks at Allen writing. A mirror between father and son. A moment of warm appreciation. Louis hands Allen a package from the mail pile. LOUIS

This came for you today. The package is from Columbia University. Allen opens it, mystified as to what it might be. It's his manuscript. On it, a note: "Walt Jr.: Keep this, Keep Going. - Profes Steeves." The music on the radio suddenly stops for a news broadcas RADIO ANNOUNCER (V.O.)
This is Bill O'Connell reporting from Paris and these are the sounds of liberation. Over the radio comes the sound of a ROARING CELEBRATION. RADIO ANNOUNCER (V.O.)
Crowds have assembled in the streets. Allen takes in the historic news. He looks at his father. world, forever changed. RADIO ANNOUNCER (V.O.)
This is the end of a long darkness. France and Europe are finally free. Crowds ERUPT in whistles and cheers. Allen takes it in. T moment Lucien had dreamed of.
The Mills Brothers' "You Always Hurt The One You Love" st to play.
Sun streaming on Allen, standing at the bank of the Hudso River, at the place where David died. ALLEN (V.O.)
Another lover hits the universe. But the night here has passed, a new day begun. It's now pastoral, shimmering. Strolling couples, families walk by Allen closes his eyes. ALLEN (V.O.)
The circle is broken.
A raucous crowd now fills the boys' old haunt. Soldiers, Yorkers of all kinds, pouring champagne, toasting the end the Second World War. ALLEN (V.O.)

But with death comes rebirth. The camera searches through the crowd to find Allen smoki in a banquette towards the rear of the bar, dressed-down, scruffy - a hint of the man he will soon become. He is joyous, writing in his journal. ALLEN (V.O.)

And like all lovers and sad people The camera then pans past Allen, up and across the old college photos on the wall. We find a framed newspaper article on the Columbia's foot team's latest victory. In the corner of the article, we see a familiar face. As we move closer, we can read the edge of the headline reads: "HONOR SLAYING." The face belongs to Lucien Carr, staring down, frozen in time. Lucien is now on the wall.
ALLEN (V.O.)
I am a poet.
The following TEXT CARDS fade up on screen.

Portraying David Kammerer as a homosexual predator, Lucie Carr pled guilty to first degree manslaughter. He served months in a reformatory. He worked as an editor at United Press International, whe he remained until his death in 2005. He married twice and had three children.

Edie Parker's family bailed out Jack Kerouac, on the condition they marry and move to Michigan. Craving friends in New York, he annulled his marriage and began a journey that would inspire his novel On the Road.

William Burroughs left his family to pursue a criminal li in New York that he documented in his novels Junkie and N Lunch. He co-wrote his first novel with Jack, a novel bas on David Kammerer's murder. It was kept from publication for over sixty years.

After his expulsion from Columbia University in 1945, All Ginsberg became one of the most awarded poets in American history. He dedicated his first published collection Howl and Othe Poems to Lucien Carr.
In response, Lucien asked that his name be withdrawn from further editions.
